Alarte Ascendare.Name: Alarte Ascendare

Alohamora.Name: Alohamora

Anteoculatia.Name: Anteoculatia

Anteoculatia.Etymology: In Spanish 'Ante; when used as a noun can refer to 'buckskin'. It is more commonly known in Latin, Spanish, Italian and Portuguese to mean 'before' or 'above . 'Oculas' in Latin means 'eyes' or 'to see'. The spell can either refer to 'buckskin', or buck-like attributes appearing. Or more vaguely, refers to something above the eyes-- where the spell appears to target.

Appare Vestigium.Name: Appare Vestigium
Appare Vestigium.Use: Used to reveal and illuminates traces of recent magical activity and shows magical footprints and track marks in an area
Appare Vestigium.Etymology: The spell has two components, appare, a Latin word in the imperative form (present active, second-person, singular meaning 'you appear (now)', a conjugation of the verb appare ('I appear, or come into sight'), and vestigium, Latin for 'footprint or track', or in a broader sense, any from of 'trace, vestige or mark'. Together, the incantation Appare Vestigium can be interpreted as a command, 'footprints, traces, you appear now'.

Apparition.Name: Apparition

Arania Exumai.Name: Arania Exumai
Arania Exumai.Use: Used to blast away Acromantulas or other large spiders
Arania Exumai.Etymology: Arania is derived from the Latin word aranea, meaning 'spider'. Exumai is possibly derived from exuo, which is Latin for 'I lay aside' or 'I refused'. Alternatively, the Pronunciation of exumai is somewhat similar to that of exime, a conjugation of eximo, which is Latin for 'I banish'. Together, the incantation can mean 'I lay aside the spider' or 'I banish the spider'.
Arania Exumai.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (disc 2)

Arresto Momentum.Name: Arresto Momentum
Arresto Momentum.Use: Used to slow the velocity of an object
Arresto Momentum.Etymology: Likely the combination of two words: the Anglo-French 'arester', meaning 'to bring to a stop', and the Latin 'Momentum', meaning 'the force or strength gained whilst moving'. Literal translation: 'bring its momentum to a stop'.
Arresto Momentum.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film) (first appearance) (first identified as Arresto Momentum), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (first identified as Slowing Charm), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Ascendio.Name: Ascendio

Ascendio.Etymology: 'Ascendio' comes from the Latin word 'ascendo', meaning 'to climb'.

Avada Kedavra.Name: Avada Kedavra
Avada Kedavra.Use: When cast, this curse causes instantaneous and painless death
Avada Kedavra.Etymology: Avada Kedavra is derived from Aramaic, avada kedavra meaning 'let the thing be destroy'. J.K. Rowling confirmed this during an audience interview at the Edinburgh Book Festival on April 15, 2004, where she had this to say about the spell's Etymology: 'Does anyone know where avada kedavra came from? It is an ancient spell in Aramaic, and it is the original abracadabra, which means 'let the thing be destroyed'. Originally, it was used to cure illness and the 'thing' was the illness, but I decided to make it the 'thing' as in the person standing in front of me. I take a lot of liberties with things like that. I twist them round and make them mine.'
Avada Kedavra.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance) (appears in flashbacks), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (appears in flashbacks), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film( (Avada only), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first identified as the Killing Curse), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2017 edition) (mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Avensegium.Name: Avensegium
Avensegium.Use: Turns a target object into a tracking device
Avensegium.Etymology: The incantation Avenseguim is likely derived from the portmanteau of avens, a Latin adjective for 'eager' or 'craving', and seguir, the Spanish and Portuguese verb meaning 'to follow', or alternatively from the Catalan seguim, meaning 'we follow'. Taken together, Avenseguim can be interpreted as 'to eagerly follow', which aptly characterizes the behavior of a tracking device
Avensegium.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Epoximise.Etymology: Epoximise comes from the English word epoxy which is a Type of adhesive. The word eposy itself has origins in Greek
Epoximise.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

Erecto.Name: Erecto

Everte Statum.Name: Everte Statum
Everte Statum.Use: Used to make an opponent fly back several feet, causing a short sharp pain depending on the strength of the spell, but does not causes any lasting damage
Everte Statum.Etymology: From Latin everte, meaning 'to throw out' and statum, meaning 'stand'. This implies that it would causes the victim to be thrown from their standing position, which most notably coincides with the effect seen in the films.
Everte Statum.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)

Expecto Patronum.Name: Expecto Patronum
Expecto Patronum.Use: Used to evoke a partially-tangible positive energy force known as a Patronus or spirit Guardian; primarily used to protect against Dementors and Lethifolds, against which there is no other defence
Expecto Patronum.Etymology: Patronus is the nominative singular case meaning 'protector', 'guardian', or simply 'patron'. In Latin, specifically reflecting the entire role that the Patronus Charm plays. In archaic Latin, it means 'father', which is very interesting, considering that Harry Potter's Patronus is the same as his father's Patronus and Animagus form, a stag. The Latin word exspecto is the first person, singular form of expectare meaning 'to await', thus the charm's incantation translates into 'I await a patron' (since patronum is the singular accusative form of patronus, meaning it is the case which a noun or an adjective describing the noun takes when it is the direct object of a sentence, which in the spell's translation, it is)
Expecto Patronum.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

Expelliarmus.Name: Expelliarmus
Expelliarmus.Use: Used to force whatever an opponent is holding to fly out of their hand
Expelliarmus.Etymology: Latin expellere (ex = out, pellere = tp drive), meaning 'to drive out' and 'arma' meaning 'weapon. Expelliarmus actually means 'to drive out the weapon'

Finestra.Name: Finestra
Finestra.Etymology: The word finestra means 'window' in Italian, Catalan and Sicilian. Given Rowling's use of puns in the construction of other incantations (e.g. Orchideous and Aguamenti), it is also possible that finestra is a sort of double entendre - a humorous blend of fine or finis, the Italian and Latin words for 'end', and finestra for window. Together, this could allude to the spell's ironic capacity to destroy windows in the creation of an opening or 'window'.
Finestra.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

Finite Incantatem.Name: Finite Incantatem

Finite Incantatem.Etymology: From Latin finire, meaning 'to end', and incantationem, meaning 'enchantment'. Finite means 'end' (imperative).

Mosmordre.Name: Mosmordre
Mosmordre.Use: Used to conjure the image of the Dark Mark, the skull-and-serpent sign used by Voldemort and his Death Eaters
Mosmordre.Etymology: The incantation of this spell appears to be derived from the Latin mors, 'death', and mordere, 'to bite'. This alludes to the name of Voldemort's followers, the Death Eaters. Another derivation may come from French mort, 'death', and mordre, 'to bite'. The English word murder could also contribute. The literal translation of the Norwegian word 'morsmodre' would be 'mothers killers'. It may also be a reference to the word 'mord', which means 'murder' in Icelandic, German, Norwegian, Danish Polish and Swedish, since the spell is cast after someone has been murdered, and sounds like 'mass murder' and 'mortal.'

Oculus Reparo.Name: Oculus Reparo
Oculus Reparo.Etymology: The word reparo is the first person singular form of the first conjugation verb (-are) reparare, meaning 'to renew' or 'to revive' in Latin. The word oculus is the nominative singular form of the word meaning 'eye'. Thus, the spell Oculus Reparo roughly means 'I renew the eye'. Unfortunately, from a grammatical point of view, this statement is incorrect, because although it follows the common SOV word order, the word oculus is in the nominative singular case, when it should be accusative singular, as it is the object of the sentence.
Oculus Reparo.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (first identified as Oculus Reparo) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire

Sectumsempra.Name: Sectumsempra

Sectumsempra.Etymology: The incantation Sectumsempra derives from the two Latin words: sectum, a participle of the verb sĕco , 'to cut', and semper, meaning 'always' or 'ever'. Since English has many words meaning 'cut' or 'lacerate', and since spell-names lend themselves to both infinitive and gerund verb forms ('to cut' and 'cutting'), Sectumsempra can be translated in more than one way: 'cut always', 'ever cutting', 'always sever', 'ever severing', and so forth.'Sever' for sectum may be regarded as a particularly appealing translation in that 'sever' creates a pun on Snape's first name, Severus'.

Tarantallegra.Name: Tarantallegra

Tarantallegra.Etymology: The Tarantella is a dance originating in Italy. It was believed to cure the effects of the bite of a Tarantula by causing the victim to sweat out the toxin. Vera Verto.Name: Vera Verto

Vera Verto.Etymology: Vera is taken from the Latin noun Fera meaning 'beast' or 'wild animal'. Verto, also Latin, is a verb that can mean 'I turn' or 'I exchange'. Collectively, Fera Verto is a Latin phrase that can be taken to mean 'I exchange the beast'.

Vipera Evanesca.Name: Vipera Evanesca
Vipera Evanesca.Etymology: Vipera is a genus of venomous vipers, a Type of snake. Evanesca likely shares its origin with Evanesco, which means 'disappear' in Latin -- Evanesca would be the imperative form of the verb, making this incantation a command for the serpent to disappear, meaning 'Viper, disappear.'
Vipera Evanesca.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first identified as Vipera Evanesca), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

Wingardium Leviosa.Name: Wingardium Leviosa
Wingardium Leviosa.Use: Used to make objects fly or levitate
Wingardium Leviosa.Etymology: Wingardium is a composite word, based on: English to wing meaning 'to fly' (e.g. the plane winged skywards);arduus (meaning 'high, tall, lofty, steep, proudly elevated') or arduum (meaning 'steep place, the steep'); and the common Latin ending -ium. Leviosa probably derives from Latin levo, meaning to 'raise, lift up', or levis, meaning light (of weight).[31][34] Altogether, therefore, the incantation could best be read as 'lift up high'.
Wingardium Leviosa.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of Phoenix (film) (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

The Seeker's goal is to catch the Snitch before the other team's seeker, which is worth one-hundred and fifty points. The game can only end when the Snitch has been caught, or by mutual agreement of the two teams' Captains; the latter is very rare, however, as one team would have to lose.[5] Going off of Ginny Weasley's statement, it would appear Snitches fly at varying speeds, or at least can wear out.

Magical Exposure Threat Level Measurer.Name: Magical Exposure Threat Level Measurer
Magical Exposure Threat Level Measurer.Owners: Magical Congress of the United States of America (MACUSA)
Magical Exposure Threat Level Measurer.Use: This measurer was a magical device used in the United States of America that measured the threat level of exposure of magic to the No-Maj people. It hung in the central foyer of the Magical Congress of the United States of America. It resembled a barometer, had four faces, and black hands. Various colours indicated the threat levels: Zero Threat (Green), Level One: Low Threat (Green), Level Two: Moderate Threat (Green), Level Three: High Alert (Blue),Level Four: Danger (Yellow), Level Five: Severe: Unexplained Activity (Orange),Level Six: Emergency (Red). There were also counters indicating how many witch hunts have ocurred, how many times witches and wizards had been exposed, and how many times the Memory Charm had been used on non-magical persons. If the wizarding community in America was close to exposure, the device sounded an alarm informing the Aurors of the impending threat.
Magical Exposure Threat Level Measurer.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

Mirror of Erised.Name: Mirror of Erised
Mirror of Erised.Owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
Mirror of Erised.Use: The Mirror of Erised was a magical mirror, which, according to Albus Dumbledore, shows the 'deepest, most desperate desire of our hearts.' The Name 'Erised' is 'desire' spelled backwards, as if reflected in a mirror. The happiest and most satisfied person in the world would look in the mirror and see a reflection of them, exactly as they were, for they would then have no one and nothing more to yearn or desire for that the mirror could ever show them. But of course, it is intrinsically inherent for human nature to desire something greater than one's own self - meaning that an event wherein the mirror fails to carry out its intended purpose rarely, if at all, happens.
Mirror of Erised.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (flashback on disc 2)

Nicolas Flamel's Crystal Ball.Use: Nicolas Flamel's crystal ball was an orb that let Nicolas see the future
Nicolas Flamel's Crystal Ball.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Oliver Wood's Quidditch Diagrams.Name: Oliver Wood's Quidditch Diagrams
Oliver Wood's Quidditch Diagrams.Use: During his time as Captain of the Gryffindor Quidditch team, Oliver Wood used a number of diagrams to show new maneuvers and tactics to his team. These diagrams could be animated with the tap of a wand to further showcase the moves in question.
Oliver Wood's Quidditch Diagrams.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only)

Omnioculars.Name: Omnioculars
Omnioculars.Owners: Harry Potter, Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger
Omnioculars.Use: Omnioculars were the wizarding equivalent of Muggle binoculars, but with the additional features of being able to magically slow down ad replay action
Omnioculars.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

Orrery.Name: Orrery
Orrery.Use: Orreries were models of the sun, planets and moons of the solar system, used for studying Astronomy. Sybill Trelawney used one of all nine planets (including Pluto) while teaching Astrology during Divination in 1995.
Orrery.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film) (possible appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance)

Owl Lecturn.Name: Owl Lecturn
Owl Lecturn.Owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
Owl Lecturn.Use: The Owl Lecturn[3] was an owl-shaped magical podium located in the Great Hall at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry,[1] that dated back to at least the late 1800s.
Owl Lecturn.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (non-canonical appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (non-canonical)

Pensieve.Name: Pensieve
Pensieve.Use: The Pensieve was a magical device used to review memories. It had the appearance of a shallow stone or metal basin, into which runes and strange symbols were carved and precious stones were fitted. It was filled with a silvery substance that appears to be a cloudy liquid/gas; the collected memories of people who had siphoned their recollections into it.
Pensieve.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and th Deathly Hallows: Part 2

Perkin's Tent.Name: Perkin's Tent
Perkin's Tent.Owners: Perkins, Weasley family (formerly), Hermione Granger, Harry Potter
Perkin's Tent.Use: Perkins, who worked with Arthur Weasley in the Misuse of Muggle Artefacts Office, owned a tent that is charmed to be larger on the inside than it appears to be on the outside, most likely with the Undetectable Extension Charm.
Perkin's Tent.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

Philosopher's Stone.Name: Philosopher's Stone
Philosopher's Stone.Use: The Philosopher's Stone was a legendary alchemical substance with magical properties. This ruby-red stone could be used to create the Elixir of Life, which made the drinker immortal, as well as transform any metal into pure gold. The only known Stone to have ever existed was created by the famed alchemist Nicolas Flamel.
Philosopher's Stone.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Phoenix Fire Lighters.Name: Phoenix Fire Lighters
Phoenix Fire Lighters.Use: Phoenix Fire Lighters is a magical brand of firelighters which, according to the information printed on the box, creates eternal fire. Molly Weasley kept a box of these fire lighters at The Burrow in the 1990s.
Phoenix Fire Lighters.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance)

Potter Memorial.Name: Potter Memorial
Potter Memorial.Use: The Potter Memorial commemorated James and Lily Potter and also included  dedication to Harry Potter
Potter Memorial.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance)

Prophecy Record.Name: Prophecy Record
Prophecy Record.Use: Prophecy Records are used to keep track of prophecies made by Seers.
Prophecy Record.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only)

Quick-Quotes Quill.Name: Quick-Quotes Quill
Quick-Quotes Quill.Use: A Quick-Quotes Quill was a magical quill that wrote automatically as the subject spoke. However, the quill did not record verbatim what the subject said, but rather took a subject's words and created sensational and inaccurate tales that bore little resemblance to actual events.
Quick-Quotes Quill.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (seen on disc 2), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (seen on book cover

Rainbow Bath Taps.Name: Rainbow Bath Taps
Rainbow Bath Taps.Owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry
Rainbow Bath Taps.Use: Rainbow Bath Taps[2] were hundreds of enchanted golden bath taps that were fitted in the Prefects' Bathroom at Hogwarts Castle.[2][1] Each of these taps ran their own differently coloured and treated bathwater and bubble baths, each with different fragrances and remedies, providing students with a relaxing experience in the special bath.
Rainbow Bath Taps.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

Remembrall.Name: Remembrall
Remembrall.Use: A Remembrall is a magical large marble-sized glass ball that contains smoke which turns red when its owner or user has forgotten something. It turns clear once whatever was forgotten is remembered.
Remembrall.Appearances: Harry Potter an the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only)

Resurrection Stone.Name: Resurrection Stone
Resurrection Stone.Owners: Cadmus Peverell, Generations of Guants, Marvolo Guant, Morfin Guant, Tom Riddle, Albus Dumbledore, Harry Potter
Resurrection Stone.Use: The Resurrection Stone was one of the fabled Deathly Hallows. In The Tale of the Three Brothers, it was the second Hallow created, supposedly by Death himself. It was bestowed upon Cadmus Peverell after he requested, as his bounty, something with the power to recall loved ones from Death. According to legend, whoever reunited it with the other two Hallows (the Elder Wand and the Cloak of Invisibility) would become the Master of Death. It was one of the two Hallows known to have been successfully passed down from generation to generation since Cadmus's time. In 1943 it passed to the possession of Tom Riddle who unknowingly stole it while it was still concealed in Marvolo Gaunt's Ring, which he turned into a Horcrux. The ring was destroyed in 1996 by Albus Dumbledore, but the stone was placed in Harry Potter's first Golden Snitch until it passed into the possession of Harry Potter who used it to great success in the Second Wizarding War.
Resurrection Stone.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first identified as the Resurrection Stone, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

Revealer.Name: Revealer
Revealer.Use: A Revealer was a magical device used to render invisible writing visible. It had the appearance of an ordinary Muggle eraser, although it had a bright red color.
Revealer.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance)

Rogue Bludger.Name: Rogue Bludger
Rogue Bludger.Owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft or Wizardry
Rogue Bludger.Use: The rogue bludger's goal was to assault and injure Harry Potter during a Quidditch match
Rogue Bludger.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)

Ronald Weasley's Wireless Radio.Name: Ronald Weasley's Wireless Radio
Ronald Weasley's Wireless Radio.Use: Ronald Weasley used his wireless radio to try to tune into Potterwatch for weeks until he figured out the password, 'Albus'.
Ronald Weasley's Wireless Radio.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

Rotating Tower.Name: Rotating Tower
Rotating Tower.Use: A Rotating tower is a tall device divided in several stacked sections. The sections magically rotate on top of each other. The purpose of this device is unknown.
Rotating Tower.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film) (appears in flashback(s)), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Self-Correcting Ink.Name: Self-Correcting Ink
Self-Correcting Ink.Use: Self-Correcting Ink was a Type of ink that presumably magically changes whatever was written with it to be correct. used of this ink was banned during exams from the Wizarding Examinations Authority, such as Ordinary Wizarding Levels.
Self-Correcting Ink.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first mentioned)

Self-Inking Quill.Name: Self-Inking Quill
Self-Inking Quill.Use: A Self-Inking Quill was a tpe of quill that probably inked itself.
Self-Inking Quill.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half Blood Prince

Self-Knitting Needles.Name: Self-Knitting Needles
Self-Knitting Needles.Use: Self-Knitting Needles are a special Type of wizarding knitting needles imbued with a charm to make them knit on their own
Self-Knitting Needles.Appearances: Harry Potter and the CHamber of Secrets (film)

Self-Operating Typewriters.Name: Self-Operating Typewriters
Self-Operating Typewriters.Owners: Magical Congress of the United States of America (MACUSA)
Self-Operating Typewriters.Use: Self-operating Typewriters were machines used for typing on pieces of paper. Self-operating Typewriters were enchanted to work automatically without needing someone to operate them.
Self-Operating Typewriters.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them - The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

Self-Shuffling Playing Cards.Name: Self-Shuffling Playing Cards
Self-Shuffling Playing Cards.Use: Self-Shuffling playing cards are charmed to shuffle themselves
Self-Shuffling Playing Cards.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance)

Shamrock Hat.Name: Shamrock Hat
Shamrock Hat.Use: A Shamrock hat was a green-coloured hat, which was decorated with Irish shamrocks, which were often worn to show support for the Irish National Quidditch team at Quidditch matches.
Shamrock Hat.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

Sirius Black's Motorbike.Name: Sirius Black's Motorbike
Sirius Black's Motorbike.Owners: Sirius Black (previous owner), Rubeus Hagrid (borrowed only), Harry Potter (owner)
Sirius Black's Motorbike.Use: This motorbike was a magical motorcycle owned by Harry Potter that previously belonged to his godfather, Sirius Black, which Harry inherited after Sirius was killed by Bellatrix Lestrange during the Battle of the Department of Mysteries. It had a large engine (suggested by the noise made when active and the fact that it could carry a sidecar). It also appeared to have a kickstart.[1] Magic made it much larger than when it was manufactured, emitting a very loud roar. When Hagrid, a half-giant, rode it, the motorbike was large enough to fit him and could still carry an ordinary-sized person in its sidecar. Another spell made it able to fly fast enough to compete with a broomstick.
Sirius Black's Motorbike.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film)

Sirius Black's Penknife.Name: Sirius Black's Penknife
Sirius Black's Penknife.Use: Sirius Black's penknife had attachments designed to open any lock and untie any knot, even if they have been protected against the Unlocking Charm or similar spells. To use the device to open a locked door, one inserted its blade into the crack between door and door frame, then slide it up and down. However, there are some doors that cannot be opened by this knife, such as the door to the Love Chamber in the Department of Mysteries. That particular lock caused the blade to melt.
Sirius Black's Penknife.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

Slughorn's Hourglass.Name: Slughorn's Hourglass
Slughorn's Hourglass.Use: The hourglass' sand ran accordingly with the quality of the conversation: if stimulating, the sand ran slowly.
Slughorn's Hourglass.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Spectrespecs.Name: Spectrespecs
Spectrespecs.Use: Spectrespecs were large, colorful spectacles that were given away free in an issue of The Quibbler in 1996. They were described as making their wearer look like a 'demented, multicolored owl.' They made wrackspurts (invisible creatures that floated through one's ears causing their brain to go fuzzy) visible to the wizarding eye, according to Luna Lovegood.
Spectrespecs.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Sum-Solving Ink.Name: Sum-Solving Ink
Sum-Solving Ink.Use: Sum-solving ink was a Type of ink that presumably helped solve mathematical problems. Luna Lovegood owned a bottle of turquoise sum-solving ink, but someone took it from her and hid it during the 1995–1996 school year, prompting her to post a notice asking for the return of it and several other missing possessions.
Sum-Solving Ink.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (first mentioned) (mentioned on a poster)

Sweeper.Name: Sweeper
Sweeper.Use: Sweepers, used to clean, consisted of a metal body with a large bag attached to the back and a hoover head at the front, as well as several limbs ending in a variety of brushes and dusters. Sweepers moved autonomously on two wheels and could lift their arms from the ground to clean raised surfaces or people. They bore a heavy resemblance to non-magical vacuum cleaners.
Sweeper.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Cave Boat.Name: Cave Boat
Cave Boat.Use: This boat was used to get to the island in the middle of the lake in the Horcrux cave, where the locket Horcrux was hidden
Cave Boat.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (appears in vision(s))

Time Turner.Name: Time Turner
Time Turner.Owners: Hermione Granger (formerly), Albus Dumbledore, Minerva McGonagall, British Ministry of Magic (destroyed)
Time Turner.Use: A Time-Turner was a magical device used for time travel. It was a special timepiece which resembled an hourglass on a necklace.
Time Turner.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only)

Two-Way Mirror.Name: Two-Way Mirror
Two-Way Mirror.Owners: James Potter, Sirius Black, Harry Potter, Mundungus Fletcher, Aberforth Dumbledore
Two-Way Mirror.Use: A two-way mirror was one in a pair of mirrors that were magically connected. This allowed people to communicate with each other whilst in different locations.
Two-Way Mirror.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

Underwater Viewing Scope.Name: Underwater Viewing Scope
Underwater Viewing Scope.Use: An Underwater Viewing Scope was a magical device used to see underwater.
Underwater Viewing Scope.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film) (cut content)

Vanishing Cabinet.Name: Vanishing Cabinet
Vanishing Cabinet.Owners: Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, Borgin and Burkes
Vanishing Cabinet.Use: A pair of Vanishing Cabinets would act as a passage between two places. If an object had been placed in one, it would appear in the other.
Vanishing Cabinet.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Par 2 (film) (appears in flashback(s))

Veil.Name: Veil
Veil.Owners: British Ministry of Magic, Department of Mysteries
Veil.Use: The Veil was an enigmatic structure located in the Department of Mysteries. It seemed to be a manifestation of the barrier between the land of the living and the land of the dead. One could not travel freely between the two worlds, as it was a one-way trip. The Unspeakables who worked in the Department of Mysteries likely studied it closely.
Veil.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (mentioned only)

Walls Pretending to be Doors.Name: Walls Pretending to be Doors
Walls Pretending to be Doors.Use: There exist walls that pretend to be doors withing Hogwarts Castle, which annoy first year students trying to find their way around
Walls Pretending to be Doors.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned)

Wand Weigher.Name: Wand Weigher
Wand Weigher.Use: This was a brass instrument used to identify a wand's length, core material, and the length of time it has been used
Wand Weigher.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

Weasley Clock.Name: Weasley Clock
Weasley Clock.Use: The Weasley Clock was a magical clock owned by the Weasley family which individually monitored each of their whereabouts. Located in the living room at The Burrow, the clock had nine golden hands, one for every member of the household.In place of hours on the clock's face were a series of possible locations, including 'home,' 'school', 'work', 'travelling', 'lost', 'hospital', 'prison', and 'mortal peril.
Weasley Clock.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film

Winged Keys.Name: Winged Keys
Winged Keys.Use: The Winged Keys, also known as Flying Keys, were keys that were enchanted with the Flying charm by Professor Filius Flitwick to guard the Philosopher's Stone.
Winged Keys.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appeared), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)

Wireless.Name: Wireless
Wireless.Use: A wireless, also referred to as a radio, is an audio sound broadcasting service and a form of long-distance communication and entertainment in the wizarding world. Unlike the Muggle variation, it is powered by magic, not electricity.
Wireless.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film)

Wizard Cracker.Name: Wizard Cracker
Wizard Cracker.Use: A Wizard Cracker (also known as a Wizarding Cracker) was a magical kind of Christmas cracker that wizards often gifted to each other around Christmas. It held a small gift inside. Unlike Muggle crackers, Wizard Crackers went off with a bang as loud as a cannon blast, enveloping everyone nearby in a cloud of blue smoke, rather than just a small pop. The gifts in comparison to the Muggle counterpart were often far more unique or genuine in quality, with the hats being as durable as the real thing, and the gifts being rather peculiar.
Wizard Cracker.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Wizard Checkers.Name: Wizard's Checkers
Wizard Checkers.Use: Wizard's Checkers was presumably a board game similar to draughts and played between two players using white and black circular pieces.
Wizard Checkers.Appearances: Fantastic Beats and Where to Find Them (film)

Ageing Potion.Name: Ageing Potion
Ageing Potion.Effect: Ageing potion is a powerful potion that causes the drinker to temporarily become older. The more of the potion that was drunk, the larger the ageing would occur
Ageing Potion.KnownIngredients: Newt spleens, bananas, an orange snake, a green leaf
Ageing Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)

Amortentia.Name: Amortentia
Amortentia.Effect: Amortentia is the most powerful love potion in existence. It causes a powerful infatuation or obsession from the drinker.
Amortentia.Characteristics: Mother-of-pearl sheen, spiraling steam, scent is multi-faceted and varies based on what the person likes
Amortentia.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Antidote to Veritaserum.Name: Antidote to Veritaserum
Antidote to Veritaserum.Effect: This antidote counters the effects of Veritaserum.
Antidote to Veritaserum.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first mentioned)

Armadillo Bile Mixture.Name: Armadillo Bile Mixture
Armadillo Bile Mixture.KnownIngredients: Bat Wings, Armadillo Bile, Wormwood, Amotentia, Acromantula Venom, Aconite, Water (likely)
Armadillo Bile Mixture.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (first appearance)

Babbling Beverage.Name: Babbling Beverage
Babbling Beverage.Effect: Babbling beverage was a potion that caused the drinker to babble nonsense
Babbling Beverage.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first mentioned)

Baruffio's Brain Elixir.Name: Baruffio's Brain Elixir
Baruffio's Brain Elixir.Effect: Baruffio's Brain Elixir was a potion that supposedly increased the drinker's brain power.
Baruffio's Brain Elixir.KnownIngredients: Leaping Toadstools, Frog Brains, Runespoor Eggs, Powdered Dragon Claw
Baruffio's Brain Elixir.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

Befuddlement Draught.Name: Befuddlement Draught
Befuddlement Draught.Effect: Befuddlement Draught was a potion which caused the drinker to become belligerent and reckless.
Befuddlement Draught.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

First Love Beguiling Bubbles.Name: First Love Beguiling Bubbles
First Love Beguiling Bubbles.Effect: First Love Beguiling Bubbles was a love potion from the WonderWitch line by Weasley's Wizard Wheezes. It causes the drinker to become infatuated with the giver of the potion.
First Love Beguiling Bubbles.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (first appearance)

Tolipan Blemish Blitzer.Name: Tolipan Blemish Blitzer
Tolipan Blemish Blitzer.Effect: Tolipan Blemish Blitzer is a potion that treats acne.
Tolipan Blemish Blitzer.Characteristics: White in color, thick paste consistency
Tolipan Blemish Blitzer.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (first mentioned), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film) (mentioned only)

Blood-Replenishing Potion.Name: Blood-Replenishing Potion
Blood-Replenishing Potion.Effect: The Blood-Replenishing potion was a healing potion that replenished blood lost from injuries or other means
Blood-Replenishing Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first mentioned)

Bruise Removal Paste.Name: Bruise Removal Paste
Bruise Removal Paste.Effect: The Bruise Removal Paste was a thick yellow healing potion, guaranteed to remove any bruise within the hour.
Bruise Removal Paste.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance)

Burn-Healing Paste.Name: Burn-Healing Paste
Burn-Healing Paste.Effect: Burn-Healing Paste was a healing potion in the form of a thick orange paste, which was used to heal burns
Burn-Healing Paste.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, (first appearance)

Calming Draught.Name: Calming Draught
Calming Draught.Effect: A Calming Draught potion was used to calm a person down after they have suffered a shock, trauma, or emotional outburst
Calming Draught.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first mentioned)

Caxambu Style Borborygmus Potion.Name: Caxambu Style Borborygmus Potion
Caxambu Style Borborygmus Potion.Effect: Caxambu Style Borborgmus Potion is a concoction that, given its Name, was developed in Caxambu, Brazil and provokes stomach growing.
Caxambu Style Borborygmus Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (first appearance)

Confusing Concoction.Name: Confusing Concoction
Confusing Concoction.Effect: The Confusion Concoction, also known as Confusing Draught, was a potion which caused confusion in the drinker
Confusing Concoction.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only)

Cure for Boils.Name: Cure for Boils
Cure for Boils.Effect: The Cure for Boils (also known as simply Boil Cure) was a potion which removed boils, such as those produced by the Pimple Jinx.
Cure for Boils.Characteristics: Blue, emits pink smoke when completed
Cure for Boils.KnownIngredients: Dried Nettles, 6 Snake Fangs, 4 Horned Slugs, 2 Porcupine Quills
Cure for Boils.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance)

Death Potion.Name: Death Potion
Death Potion.Effect: This potion was a black potion contained within the Death Cell at the Magical Congress of the United States of America. It was used to carry out executions in the 1920s, especially in 1926 with the failed death sentence of Porpentina Goldstein.
Death Potion.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them: The Original Screenplay (first appearance), Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (film)

Deflating Draught.Name: Deflating Draught
Deflating Draught.Effect: The Deflating Draught was a potion that caused anything swollen by magical means to shrink back to normal size. This was the opposite of a Swelling Solution and acted as an antidote to it.
Deflating Draught.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance)

Doxycide.Name: Doxycide
Doxycide.Effect: Doxycide was a black-coloured, foul smelling potion used to spray Doxies. It paralyzed them for a period of time, allowing the user to safely remove the Doxies without fear of being bitten. The recipe could be found in Book of Potions.
Doxycide.Characteristics: Black, typically delivered as a spray
Doxycide.KnownIngredients: Bundimun Ooze, Streeler Shells, Dragon Liver, Hemlock Essence, Torentil Tincture, Cowbane Essence
Doxycide.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

Dr Ubbly's Oblivious Unction.Name: Dr. Ubbly's Oblivious Unction
Dr Ubbly's Oblivious Unction.Effect: Dr Ubbly's Oblivious Unction was a medicinal potion given to Ron Weasley by Poppy Pomfrey after he had been attacked by brains in the Department of Mysteries. It proved mostly effective in healing the injuries caused by the brains' tentacles and thoughts,[1] though several months later there was still at least some scarring left.
Dr Ubbly's Oblivious Unction.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

Draught of Living Death.Name: Draught of Living Death
Draught of Living Death.Effect: The Draught of Living Death was an extremely powerful Sleeping Draught, sending the drinker into a deathlike slumber. Its effects are similar to suspended animation. This draught is an advanced potion, taught to sixth year N.E.W.T. students at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
Draught of Living Death.Characteristics: Turns a pale lilac color and then clear
Draught of Living Death.KnownIngredients: Standard Potioning Water, Powdered Root of Asphodel, Infusion of Wormwood, Valerian root, One Sopophorous bean, One Sloth Brain, Moondew, Flower Head
Draught of Living Death.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (mentioned in deleted scene), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Draught of Peace.Name: Draught of Peace
Draught of Peace.Effect: The Draught of Peace was a potion which relieved anxiety and agitation. Its ingredients were powdered moonstone, syrup of hellebore, powdered porcupine quills, and powdered unicorn horn. It should have been a turquoise blue colour when finished, and simmered before being consumed.
Draught of Peace.KnownIngredients: Powdered Moonstone, Syrup of Hellebore, Powdered Unicorn Horn, Powdered Porcupine Quills, Valerian Root
Draught of Peace.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

Dreamless Sleep Potion.Name: Dreamless Sleep Potion
Dreamless Sleep Potion.Effect: The Dreamless Sleep Potion, also known as the Potion for Dreamless Sleep, is used to induce drowsiness and, if don't properly, provides a dreamless sleep for the drinker
Dreamless Sleep Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance)

Drink of Despair.Name: Drink of Despair
Drink of Despair.Effect: The Drink of Despair, also know as the Emerald Potion, was a mysterious potion which induces fear, delirium, intense stomach pain and extreme thirst in the drinker
Drink of Despair.Characteristics: Emerald green in color, glows phosphorescently
Drink of Despair.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (appears in vision(s)), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (appears in vision(s))

Elixir of Life.Name: Elixir of Life
Elixir of Life.Effect: The Elixir of Life was a potion procured from the Philosopher's Stone that made the drinker immortal, as long as they consumed the potion on a regular basis.
Elixir of Life.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay (indirectly mentioned only), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film) (indirectly mentioned only)

Elixir to Induce Euphoria.Name: Elixir to Induce Euphoria
Elixir to Induce Euphoria.Effect: The Elixir to Induce Euphoria is a sunshine-yellow potion that induces a sense of inexplicable, irrational happiness upon the drinker.
Elixir to Induce Euphoria.Characteristics: Sunshine yellow in color, emits rainbow when finished
Elixir to Induce Euphoria.KnownIngredients: Shrivelfig, Porcupine Quills, Peppermint Sprigs, Sopophorous Beans, Wormwood
Elixir to Induce Euphoria.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first-appearance)

Essence of Insanity.Name: Essence of Insanity
Essence of Insanity.Effect: Essence of Insanity was a potion which caused irrational decision making in the drinker.
Essence of Insanity.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first mentioned)

Everlasting Elixir.Name: Everlasting Elixir
Everlasting Elixir.Effect: Everlasting Elixirs were a Type of potion with the effect to either never run out of potion of for the potion to work forever.
Everlasting Elixir.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first mentioned)

Felix Felicis.Name: Felix Felicis
Felix Felicis.Effect: Felix Felicis, also called 'Liquid Luck', was a potion that made the drinker lucky for a period of time,, during which everything they attempt would be successful. It turned an ordinary day into an extraordinary one.
Felix Felicis.Characteristics: Molten gold in color, droplets leap like goldfish above the potion's surface when in the cauldron
Felix Felicis.KnownIngredients: Ashwinder Egg, Squill Bulb, Murtlap Tentacle, Tincture of Thyme, Occamy Eggshell, Powdered Common Rue
Felix Felicis.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film) (possible appearance)

Fergus Fungal Budge.Name: Fergus Fungal Budge
Fergus Fungal Budge.Effect: Fergus Fungal Budge was a kind of medical dressing soaked with a fungicidal product, that treated ringworm infections on the feet.
Fergus Fungal Budge.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (film) (first mentioned) (mentioned in a newspaper)

Fire Protection Potion.Name: Fire Protection Potion
Fire Protection Potion.Effect: The Fire Protection Potion,[4][5] also known as the Ice Potion,[6] was a potion used to move through flames unscathed. When drunk, it induces a sensation of ice and frigidity in the drinker, and provides protection from most magical fires.
Fire Protection Potion.KnownIngredients: Bursting mushrooms, Salamander blood, Wartcap powder
Fire Protection Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance)

Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent.Name: Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent
Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent.Effect: Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent was a pesticide potion used to get rid of Flesh-Eating Slugs.
Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first appearance)

Forgetfulness Potion.Name: Forgetfulness Potion
Forgetfulness Potion.Effect: The Forgetfulness Potion was a potion which caused an unknown degree of memory loss in the drinker.
Forgetfulness Potion.KnownIngredients: 2 drops of Lethe River water, 2 Valerian sprigs, 2 measures of Standard Ingredient, 4 mistletoe berries
Forgetfulness Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film) (mentioned in a a deleted scene)

Garrotting Gas.Name: Garrotting Gas
Garrotting Gas.Effect: A colorless gas, Garrotting Gas is produced as a result of the creation of a certain potion. Anyone exposed to the gas, will find themselves choking and as a result, may suffocate, as the gas catches people by the neck if they pass through it.
Garrotting Gas.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first mentioned)

Hair-Raising Potion.Name: Hair-Raising Potion
Hair-Raising Potion.Effect: The Hair-Raising Potion was a potion that caused the drinker's hair to stand on end.
Hair-Raising Potion.KnownIngredients: Rat tails, Porcupine quills, Billwig stings
Hair-Raising Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first mentioned)

Hiccoughing Solution.Name: Hiccoughing Solution
Hiccoughing Solution.Effect: A potion that presumably causes hiccoughing
Hiccoughing Solution.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Invigoration Draught.Name: Invigoration Draught
Invigoration Draught.Effect: A potion that presumably boosted the drinker's energy.
Invigoration Draught.KnownIngredients: Alihotsy leaves, Dried billwig stings, Peppermint, Stewed Mandrake, Infusion of Wormwood, Honeywater, Vervain Infusion, Scurvy grass, Lovage
Invigoration Draught.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (first appearance)

Laxative Potion.Name: Laxative Potion
Laxative Potion.Effect: A potion that is most likely a laxative.
Laxative Potion.KnownIngredients: Two scrumples of an unknown ingredient, an ingredient used in a furnace, Agrimonia
Laxative Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film) (first mentioned)

Love Potion Antidote.Name: Love Potion Antidote
Love Potion Antidote.Effect: The Love Potion Antidote was a potion that cured the symptoms of any love potion in an individual.
Love Potion Antidote.KnownIngredients: Wiggentree twigs, Castor oil, Extract of Gurdyroot
Love Potion Antidote.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Mandrake Restorative Draught.Name: Mandrake Restorative Draught
Mandrake Restorative Draught.Effect: The Mandrake Restorative Draught[2] was a healing potion used to restore those who have been transfigured or cursed to their original state. It required Mandrake roots that have been matured past the stage of adolescence.
Mandrake Restorative Draught.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first mentioned), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)

Memory Potion.Name: Memory Potion
Memory Potion.Effect: A Memory Potion was a potion which improved the drinker's memory, boosting their mental cognition.
Memory Potion.KnownIngredients: Jobberknoll feathers, Stewed Mandrake, Powdered Sage, Galanthus Nivalis
Memory Potion.Appearances: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (first mentioned)

Mouth Itching Antidote.Name: Mouth Itching Antidote
Mouth Itching Antidote.Effect: The Mouth Itching Antidote was a healing potion to cure mouth itching.
Mouth Itching Antidote.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film) (first appearance)

Murtlap Essence.Name: Murtlap Essence
Murtlap Essence.Effect: Murtlap Essence soothes painful cuts and abrasions, and helps them to heal
Murtlap Essence.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix

Pepperup Potion.Name: Pepperup Potion
Pepperup Potion.Effect: The Pepperup Potion cured the common cold and warmed the recipient up.
Pepperup Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire

Polyjuice Potions.Name: Polyjuice Potion
Polyjuice Potions.Effect: The Polyjuice Potion was a potion that allowed the drinker to assume the form of someone else.
Polyjuice Potions.Characteristics: Before addition of final ingredient: Thick and mud-like, Bubbles slowly; After addition of final ingredient: Taste and color vary depending on the person being turned into
Polyjuice Potions.KnownIngredients: Lacewing flies (stewed for 21 days), Leeches, Powdered bicorn horn, Knotgrass, Fluxweed (picked at the full moon), Shredded Boomslang skin, A bit of the person you want to turn into (typically hair)
Polyjuice Potions.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film) (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (film), Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald - The Original Screenplay, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (film)

Rat Tonic.Name: Rat Tonic
Rat Tonic.Effect: Rat Tonic was a healing potion for rats. It was used to treat ageing rats
Rat Tonic.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (first appearance)

Regeneration Potion.Name: Regeneration Potion
Regeneration Potion.Effect: This potion was an 'old piece of dark magic' that restores a wizard whose body has become maimed and disfigured to their true and whole bodily form
Regeneration Potion.Characteristics: Fiery sparks when begun, Poisonous blue when the bone is added, Burning red when the flesh is added, Blinding white becoming steam when blood is added
Regeneration Potion.KnownIngredients: Bone of father, Flesh of a servant, Blood of a foe
Regeneration Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (mentioned only)

Rudimentary Body Potion.Name: Rudimentary Body Potion
Rudimentary Body Potion.Effect: This potion helps restore non-corporeal wizards to a rudimentary bodies/sustains rudimentary bodies
Rudimentary Body Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first mentioned

Scintillation Solution.Name: Scintillation Solution
Scintillation Solution.Characteristics: Turquoise in color, sparkling upon completion
Scintillation Solution.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets

Shrinking Solution.Name: Shrinking Solution
Shrinking Solution.Effect: The Shrinking Solution, also known as the Shrinking Potion, is a potion that causes the drinker to shrink to a smaller form. It is bright green when brewed correctly and, if prepared incorrectly, it can apparently be poisonous.
Shrinking Solution.KnownIngredients: Minced daisy roots, Peeled Shrivelfig, Sliced caterpillars, One rat spleen, a dash of leech juice, a splash of cowbane, Wormood
Shrinking Solution.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban

Skele-Gro.Name: Skele-Gro
Skele-Gro.Effect: Skele-Gro (alternately spelled Skelegro) was a dreadful-tasting potion which restored bones. It was able to mend broken bones, or even regrow entire bones that have vanished or been otherwise lost. For regrowing entire bones, the process was a notably slow and painful process that could take over a full day.
Skele-Gro.Characteristics: Smokes when poured, Vile tasting, Burns on the way down, Yellow in color
Skele-Gro.KnownIngredients: 1 Chinese Chomping Cabbage, 3 Puffer-fish, 5 Scarab Beetles, 1 Fanged Geranium, 1 arm bone, 1 red spider
Skele-Gro.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film), Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (mentioned only), Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

Sleekeazy's Hair Potion.Name: Sleekeazy's Hair Potion
Sleekeazy's Hair Potion.Effect: Sleekeazy's Hair Potion and Scalp Treatment was a hair care potion and scalp treatment that was invented by Fleamont Potter. It was originally sold with the slogan 'Two drops tames even the most bothersome barnet'.

Sleekeazy's Hair Potion.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (first mentioned)

Sleeping Draught.Name: Sleeping Draught

Ten-Second Pimple Vanish.Appearances: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (first appearance), Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)

Acaia.Notes: A very unusual wand wood which created tricky wands that often refused to produce magic for any but their owner, and also withheld their best effects from all but those most gifted. This sensitivity rendered them difficult to place, and Garrick Ollivander kept only a small stock for those witches or wizards of sufficient subtlety, for acacia was not suited to what was commonly known as 'bangs-and-smells' magic. When well-matched, an acacia wand matched any for power, though it was often underrated due to the peculiarity of its temperament. Acacia wands were not used often, as in the wrong hands it would either be overpowered or extremely weak.

Alder.Notes: Alder was an unyielding wood. Garrick Ollivander had discovered that its ideal owner was not stubborn or obstinate, but often helpful, considerate and most likeable. Whereas most wand woods sought similarity in the characters of those they would best serve, alder was unusual in that it seemed to desire a nature that was, if not precisely opposite to its own, certainly of a markedly different type. When an alder wand was happily placed, it became a magnificent, loyal helpmate. Of all wand types, alder was best suited to non-verbal spell work, whence came its reputation for being suitable only for the most advanced witches and wizards.

Apple.Notes: Applewood wands were not made in great numbers. They were powerful and best suited to an owner of high aims and ideals, as this wood mixed poorly with Dark magic.

Ash.Notes: Ash wands cleaved to its one true master and ought not to be passed on or gifted from the original owner, because it would lose power and skill. This tendency was extreme if the core was of unicorn hair. Those witches and wizards best suited to ash wands were not lightly swayed from their beliefs or purposes. However, the brash or over-confident witch or wizard, who often insisted of trying wands on this prestigious wood, would be disappointed by its effects. The ideal owner might be stubborn, and would certainly be courageous, but never crass or arrogant.

Aspen.Notes: The proper owner of the aspen wand was often an accomplished duellist or destined to be so, for the aspen wand was one of those particularly suited to martial magic. An infamous and secretive eighteenth-century duelling club, which called itself the Silver Spears, was reputed to admit only those who owned aspen wands.

Beech.Notes: The true match for a beech wand would be, if young, wise beyond his or her years, and if full-grown, rich in understanding and experience. Beech wands performed very weakly for the narrow-minded and intolerant. When properly matched, the beech wand was capable of a subtlety and artistry not seen in any other wood, hence its lustrous reputation.

Birch.Notes: Though Garrick Ollivander himself did not use it, his associate in the Hogsmeade branch was known to sell wands made from birch.

Blackthorn.Notes: Blackthorn wands, which was a very unusual wand wood, had the reputation, in Garrick Ollivander's well-merited opinion, of being best suited to a warrior. These wands appeared to need to pass through danger or hardship with their owners to become truly bonded. Given this condition, the blackthorn wand would become as loyal and faithful a servant as one could wish.

Black Walnut.Notes: Less common than the standard walnut wand, that of black walnut sought a master of good instincts and powerful insight. Black walnut was a very handsome wood, but not the easiest to master. Paired with a sincere, self-aware owner, however, it became one of the most loyal and impressive wands of all, with a particular flair in all kinds of charm work.

Cedar.Notes: The cedar wand found its perfect home where there were perspicacity and perception. Something that went against Slughorn's personality, as he was not particularly perceptive. The witch or wizard who was well-matched with cedar carried the potential to be a frightening adversary, which often came as a shock to those who had thoughtlessly challenged them.

Cherry.Notes: Cherry wood was a highly praised and sought after wood among Mahoutokoro students in Japan. This wand was considered expensive, possibly because of the wood it was made out of.

Chestnut.Notes: Chestnut wands preferred witches and wizards who were skilled tamers of magical beasts, those who possessed great gifts in Herbology, and those who were natural fliers.

Cypress.Notes: Cypress wands were said to be well-matched to wizards who were self-sacrificing and willing to die a heroic death. Lupin spent the majority of his life alone to save others from having to deal with the consequences of his affliction and died defending Hogwarts castle in the Battle of Hogwarts.

Dogwood.Notes: Dogwood wands were quirky and mischievous; they had playful natures and insisted upon partners who could provide them with scope for excitement and fun. It would be quite wrong, however, to deduce from this that dogwood wands were not capable of serious magic when called upon to do so; they had been known to perform outstanding spells under difficult conditions, and when paired with a suitably clever and ingenious witch or wizard, could produce dazzling enchantments. Dogwood wands refused to perform non-verbal spells and they were often rather noisy.

Ebony.Notes: Ebony wands had an impressive appearance and reputation, being highly suited to all manner of combative magic, and to Transfiguration. Ebony was happiest in the hand of those with the courage to be themselves. Frequently non-conformist, highly individual or comfortable with the status of outsider. In the experience of Garrick Ollivander, the ebony wand's perfect match was one who would hold fast to their beliefs, no matter what the external pressure, and would not be swayed lightly from their purpose.

Elder.Notes: Elder was the rarest wand wood of all and reputed to be deeply unlucky, and elder wands were trickier to master than any other. They contained powerful magic, but scorned to remain with an owner who was not the superior of their company; it took a remarkable wizard to keep an elder wand for any length of time. Only a highly unusual person would find their perfect match in the elder, and on the rare occasion when such a pairing occurred, it might be taken as certain that the witch or wizard in question was marked out for a special destiny.

Elm.Notes: Elm wands preferred owners with presence, magical dexterity and a certain native dignity. Of all wand woods, elm, in Ollivander's experience, produced the fewest accidents, the least foolish errors, and the most elegant charms and spells; these were sophisticated wands, capable of highly advanced magic in the right hands (which made it highly desirable to those who espoused the pure-blood philosophy).

English Oak.Notes: A wand for good times and bad, this was a friend as loyal as the wizard who deserved it. Wands of English oak demanded partners of strength, courage, and fidelity.

Fir.Notes: Fir wands demanded staying power and strength of purpose in their true owners, and that they were poor tools in the hands of the changeable and indecisive. Fir wands were particularly suited to Transfiguration, and favoured owners of focused, strong-minded and, occasionally, intimidating demeanor. Fir wands were called 'the survivor's wand'.

Hawthorn.Notes: Hawthorn wands might be particularly suited to healing magic, but they were also adept at curses, and it had been generally observed that the hawthorn wand seemed most at home with a conflicted nature, or with a witch or wizard passing through a period of turmoil. Hawthorn was not easy to master, however, and one should only ever consider placing a hawthorn wand in the hands of a witch or wizard of proven talent.

Hazel.Notes: Hazel wands often reflected its owner's emotional state and worked best for a master who understood and could manage their own feelings. Others should be very careful handling a hazel wand if its owner had recently lost their temper, or suffered a serious disappointment because the wand would absorb such energy and discharge it unpredictably. It was capable of outstanding magic in the hands of the skilful and was so devoted to its owner that it often 'wilted' at the end of their master's life. Hazel wands also had the unique ability to detect water underground and would emit silvery, tear-shaped puffs of smoke if passing over concealed springs and wells.

Holly.Notes: Holly wands worked most happily for those who might need help overcoming a tendency to anger and impetuosity. At the same time, holly wands often chose owners who were engaged in some dangerous and often spiritual quest.

Hornbeam.Notes: Hornbeam selected for its life mate the talented witch or wizard with a single, pure passion, which some might call obsession - more kindly - vision, which would almost always be realized. Hornbeam wands adapted more quickly than almost any other to their owner's style of magic and would become so personalized, so quickly, that other people would find them extremely difficult to use even for the most simple of spells. Hornbeam wands likewise absorbed their owner's code of honour, whatever that might be, and would refuse to perform acts - whether for good or ill - that did not tally with their master's principles. A particularly fine-tuned and sentient wand.

Ivy.Notes: Though Garrick Ollivander himself did not use it, his associate in the Hogsmeade branch was known to sell wands made from ivy.

Larch.Notes: Larch wands had a reputation for instilling confidence and courage in the user. The celebrated wand maker Garrick Ollivander found that larch always created wands of hidden talents and unexpected effects, which likewise described the master who deserved it. It was often the case that the witch or wizard who belonged to the larch wand might never realise the full extent of their considerable talents until paired with it, but that they would then make an exceptional match.

Laurel.Notes: It was said that a laurel wand couldn't perform a dishonorable act, although, in the quest for glory (a not uncommon goal for those best suited to these wands), laurel wands had been known to perform powerful and sometimes lethal magic.

Mahogany.Notes: The mahogany tree symbolized strength, safety, protectiveness, and practicality.

Maple.Notes: Their ideal owners were nature travellers and explorers; they were not stay-at-home wands and preferred ambition in their witch or wizard, otherwise, their magic grew heavy and lackluster. Fresh challenges and regular changes of scene caused this wand to literally shine, burnishing itself as it grew, with its partner, inability, and status.

Pear.Notes: Pear trees produced wands of splendid magical powers. Possessors of pear wands were, in the experience of the learned wand maker Garrick Ollivander, usually popular and well-respected and he never knew of a single instance where a pear wand had been discovered in the possession of a Dark Witch or Wizard. They were also the most resilient.

Pine.Notes: Pine wands always chose an independent, individual master who might be perceived as a loner, intriguing and perhaps mysterious. Pine wands enjoyed being used creatively, and unlike some others, would adapt unprotestingly to new methods and spells. Many wand makers insisted that pine wands were able to detect, and perform best for, owners who were destined for long lives, including Garrick Ollivander who had never personally known the master of a pine wand to die young. The pine wand was one of those that were most sensitive to non-verbal magic.

Poplar.Notes: Poplar wands relied upon consistency, strength and uniform power, and were always the happiest when working with a witch or wizard of clear moral vision. The existence of these wands and its owners was cited as evidence against a myth that poplar wands never chose politicians.

Red Oak.Notes: The true match for a red oak wand was possessed of unusually fast reactions, making it a perfect duelling wand. Less common than the English oak, its ideal master was light of touch, quick-witted and adaptable, often the creator of distinctive spells, and good person to have beside in a fight. Red oak wands were, in Ollivander's opinion, among the most handsome.

Redwood.Notes: Redwood wands were strongly attracted to witches and wizards who already possessed the admirable ability to fall on their feet, to make the right choice, to snatch advantage from catastrophe.

Reed.Notes: Though Garrick Ollivander himself did not use it, his associate in the Hogsmeade branch was known to sell wands made from reed. Corresponded to one of the months of the Celtic calendar, from 28 October to 24 November.

Rowan.Notes: Rowan wands generally produced powerful, hard-to-break Defensive Charms. Rowan wands were also noted for its believed disassociation with the Dark Arts. Perhaps for these reasons, Rowan had become associated with pure-hearted wizards, though Ollivander noted that Rowan wands could also match and even outperform others in duels.

Silver Lime.Notes: According to Pottermore, silver lime was an incredibly unusual and attractive wood that worked best for Seers and those skilled at Legilimency. It was greatly in vogue in the nineteenth century when the demand outstripped supply, causing some wand makers to dye other wood in an effort to fool purchasers into believing they had purchased a silver lime wand.

Spruce.Notes: Spruce wands required particular deftness to work with spruce, which produced wands that were ill-matched with cautious or nervous natures, becoming positively dangerous in fumbling fingers. Spruce wands required a firm hand because it often appeared to have its own ideas about what magic it ought to be called upon to produce. However, when a spruce wand met its match, who was a bold spell-caster with a good sense of humour, it became a superb helper, intensely loyal to their owners and capable of producing particularly flamboyant and dramatic effects.

Sycamore.Notes: The sycamore made a questing wand, eager for new experience and losing brilliance if engaged in mundane activities. It was a quirk of these handsome wands that they might combust if allowed to become 'bored', and many witches and wizards, settling down into middle age, were disconcerted to find their trusty wand bursting into flame in their hand as they asked it, one more time, to fetch their slippers. As may be deduced, the sycamore's ideal owner was curious, vital and adventurous, and when paired with such an owner, it demonstrated a capacity to learn and adapt that earned it a rightful place among the world's most highly-prized wand woods.

Tamarack.Notes: Its wood was known for wand making in the United States.

Vine.Notes: Vine wands were among the less common types, and their ideal owners were nearly always those witches or wizards who sought a greater purpose, who had a vision beyond the ordinary and who frequently astounded those who thought they knew them best. Vine wands seemed strongly attracted by personalities with hidden depths, and Garrick Ollivander himself had found them more sensitive than any other when it came to instantly detect a prospective match.

Walnut.Notes: Walnut wands were often found in the hands of magical innovators and inventors; this was a handsome wood possessed of unusual versatility and adaptability. Walnut wands would, once subjugated, perform any task its owner desired, provided that the user was of sufficient brilliance. This made for a truly lethal weapon in the hands of a witch or wizard of no conscience, for the wand and the wizard might feed on each other in a particularly unhealthy manner.

Willow.Notes: Willow was an uncommon wand wood with healing power, and their ideal owner often had some (usually unwarranted) insecurity, however well they might try and hide it. They had a handsome appearance and well-founded reputation for enabling advanced, non-verbal magic. The willow wands there had consistently selected those of greatest potential, rather than those who felt they had little to learn.

Yew.Notes: Yew wands were among the rarer kinds, and their ideal matches were likewise unusual and occasionally notorious. The wand of yew was reputed to endow its possessor with the power of life and death, which might, of course, be said of all wands; and yet yew retained a particularly dark and fearsome reputation in the spheres of duelling and all curses. However, it is untrue to say (as those unlearned in wandlore often did) that those who used yew wands were more likely to be attracted to the Dark Arts than another. The witch or wizard best suited to a yew wand might equally prove a fierce protector of others. Wands hewn from these most long-lived trees had been found in the possession of heroes quite as often as of villains. Where wizards had been buried with wands of yew, the wand generally sprouted into a tree guarding the dead owner's grave. What was certain, in Ollivander's experience, was that the yew wand never chose either a mediocre or a timid owner.

Acromantula.Name: Acromantula
Acromantula.Distinction(s): Capable of human speech, taste for human flesh, cannibalistic
